did.abstract: Collection contains organizational charts, annual reports, company directories, internal communications, engineering reports, design materials, press releases, manuals, public relations materials, human resource information, videotapes, audiotapes, software, hardware, and corporate memorabilia. Also includes information regarding the Board of Directors and their decisions.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: The hardware series of this collection is closed until it can be fully arranged and described.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: Property rights reside with the repository. Literary rights reside with the creators of the documents or their heirs. To obtain permission to publish or reproduce, please contact the Public Services Librarian of the Dept. of Special Collections.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item] Apple Computer, Inc. Records, M1007, Dept. of Special Collections, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, Calif.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Apple Computer, Inc. was incorporated on January 3, 1977. Apple Computer, Inc., ignited the personal computer revolution in the 1970s with the Apple II, and reinvented the personal computer in the 1980s with the Macintosh, of which it had sold more 30 million systems as of the end of 1998. Apple's original mission as articulated by its co-founder Steven Jobs was to bring the best personal computing products and support to students, educators, designers, scientists, engineers, business persons and consumers in over 140 countries around the world. In 1998, Apple Computer, Inc. maintained Research & Development sites in Cork, Ireland; Cupertino, California; Tokyo, Japan; and Zhuhai, China. Apple owned manufacturing facilities in the United States, Ireland, and Singapore. Distribution facilities are located in the United States, Europe, Canada, Australia, Singapore, and Japan.

chronitem.event: Steve Job and Steve Wozniak create the Apple computer, which is just a circuit board and does not come with a case, keyboard, mouse or monitor. Venture capitalist "Mike" Markkula invests $91,000 in the new company.
The Apple II released. First personal computer with a plastic case and color graphics.
Storage peripheral on Apple II changed from cassette to disk drive.
Apple II+ released.
Apple III released. Apple has several thousand employees, no domestic unions and goes public at $22/share.

Problems with Apple III lead the company to temporarily halt production. Forty employees are laid off. Wozniak and girlfriend injured in a plane crash. Jobs becomes chairman, "Apple Values" drafted. IBM releases its first PC.

Apple III+, Apple IIe and Lisa released. Lisa was the first graphical-interface computer available to the public. Lisa also comes with a mouse and a 3.5 inch disk drive. John Sculley leaves PepsiCola to run Apple. Over 200 Apple employees have become millionaires since 1980. Apple is the youngest company to enter the Fortune 500.
Apple IIc, Lisa 2 and Macintosh are released. The classic "1984" commercial runs during the Superbowl.
Lisa and Apple III discontinued. Lisa 2 re-released as Mac XL. Jobs resigns, Apple lays off 1200 employees and begins to look into Microsoft's GUI development after the release of Windows 1.01.
Apple IIgs, enhanced Apple IIc and MacPlus released. Apple achieves Fortune 200 classification.
Mac SE and Mac II released. Hypercard added to operating system.
Apple IIc+ and Mac IIx released. Apple has over 9000 employees worldwide and is doing business in 85 countries. Jobs' new project NeXT is released.
Mac SE/30, Mac IIcx, Mac portable and Mac IIci released. Excess Lisa computers buried in a Utah landfill.
Mac IIfx, Mac Classic, Mac LC and Mac IIsi released. IBM released Windows 3.0.
Classic II (later sold as Performa 200), Quadra 700, Quadra 900 and PowerBook 170 released.
Mac IIvx (Performa 600 and 600CD), Mac IIvi, Quadra 950 and PowerBook 160 released.

Color Classic, Color Classic II, LC III, LC III+, LC 475/ Quadra 605, LC 520, Quadra 610, Quadra 650, Quadra 800, Workgroup Server 80, PowerBook 165, PowerBook 5300 and Newton released. Scully leaves and Michael Spindler becomes CEO of Apple. NeXT computers are discontinued.
LC 550, Quadra 630, PowerMac 6100 and various Performas released.
Various PowerMacs, various Performas and Duo 2300c released. Apple has $1 billion in backorders. Windows 95 released.
Various PowerMacs and Performas released. Spindler resigns and Gil Amelio becomes chairman. Apple buys NeXT and Jobs returns to work at Apple.
Various PowerMacs and PowerBooks released. Amelio resigns. Jobs becomes "interim" CEO and crafts an alliance with Microsoft. Newton cancelled.
iMac released. Apple begins to be profitable again.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Contains organizational charts, annual reports, company directories, internal communications, engineering reports, design materials, press releases, manuals, public relations materials, human resource information, videotapes, audiotapes, software, hardware, and corporate memorabilia. Also includes information regarding the Board of Directors and their decisions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series includes organization charts (both company-wide and for smaller divisions), telephone directories, annual reports, corporate histories and timelines.

scopecontent.p: This subseries includes Apple-produced videotapes documenting Apple Computer's annual World Wide Developers conferences. Primarily represented are video materials from 1992, 1995, and 1996 as well as a small number of tapes from 1990 and 1994.

scopecontent.p: Apple 10 year anniversary video; pebble dropped into pond; ripples extend from splash; visual montage of Apple history - Jobs, Wozniak, old Apple computers, CG images, TV commercial excerpts, print ads, Annual Sales Conference and Shareholders' Meeting excerpts, screen shots, Apple executives. Closes with logo, "power", (c) 1987.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Examines successful American businesses by focusing on themes of innovation, productivity through people and shared values. IBM, Apple Computers, McDonald's and Disney World serve as examples in a behind the scenes look at their operations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Features 30 minutes of highlights from April through June 1991. The video begins with a 15 minute conversation with John Sculley on the events of the past few months. Highlights and events from the quarter include: System 7.0's intro, the layoffs, a Manufacturing update, Apple's contribution to worthy social causes, a look at QuickTime, examples of our changing channels, clips of recent marketing tools including a selection of ads from around the world, and Apple's letter of intent with IBM.
